summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.
text1: @Jackie_Onassis_: In one of the coldest places on Earth the still-active volcano of Deception Island has a dangerous whaling past.
text2: @SmithsonianMag: The whaling industry killed nearly 3 million for their oil researchers estimate

The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.
text1: @BBC_Travel: The still-active volcano of Deception Island in #Antarctica has a dangerous whaling past.
text2: @SmithsonianMag: The whaling industry killed nearly 3 million for their oil researchers estimate

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.
text1: @BiodiversityNew: World's whaling slaughter tallied
text2: @SenatorSurfer: Possibly the largest cull of any animal in human history. #Whaling slaughter tallied via @nature. -

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.
text1: Japan must end whaling and dolphin hunting. They must increase Australian pork imports. This is a must before we can negotiate. #Tweet4Taiji
text2: @SenatorSurfer: Possibly the largest cull of any animal in human history. #Whaling slaughter tallied via @nature. -

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.
text1: @DavidBooker25: #THRILLER YAKUZA'S REVENGE What if whaling resumed illegally around Maui the mating waters of the humpback whales?
text2: @SenatorSurfer: Possibly the largest cull of any animal in human history. #Whaling slaughter tallied via @nature. -

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.

summary1: During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Sea Shepherd Conservation Society contends that Japan, as well as Iceland and Norway, is in violation of the IWC moratorium on all commercial whaling. Japanese whaling is currently conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research, using the scientific research provision in the IWC agreement. The whale meat from these scientific whale hunts is sold in shops and restaurants. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that the Japanese whaling program in the Southern Ocean, begun in 2005 and called "JARPA II", was not for scientific purposes and ordered the cessation of JARPA II in March 2014. Japanese whaling hunts are a source of conflict between pro- and anti-whaling countries and organizations. Nations, scientists and environmental organizations opposed to whaling consider the Japanese research program to be unnecessary, and that it is a thinly disguised commercial whaling operation. Greenpeace argues that whales are endangered and must be protected. Japanese whaling activities have historically extended far outside Japanese territorial waters. Factory ships were not used by Japan until the 1930s. As whale catches diminished in coastal waters, Japan looked to Antarctica.
